item.title: Building Event Center: Karrotâ€™s User Event Management Platform
item.content:encoded:
The Journey from Restructuring User Event Conventions to Building an AdminÂ Platform

Hi there! Iâ€™m Mika, a frontend engineer on Karrotâ€™s DataÂ team.

At Karrot, massive amounts of user events are collected every day. These events are essential for designing experiments, improving our products, and making data-driven decisions. But as the logs scaled, managing them effectively became increasingly important.

Thatâ€™s why we restructured our company-wide logging convention and built a platform called Event Centerâ€Šâ€”â€Šan admin platform for managing user events across the company. We shifted from a Git-based, code-centric workflow to a UI-driven approach, automating as much manual work as possible. The goal was to handle user events more consistently andÂ safely.

In this post, Iâ€™ll share our journeyâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom why we restructured our logging system to how we designed and implemented Event Center. If youâ€™re dealing with similar challenges, hopefully this gives you someÂ ideas!

1. User Events: The Starting Point for Data-Driven Decisions

Millions of users interact with the Karrot app every day, leaving behind traces of their behavior. Small actions like â€œviewed a marketplace listing,â€ â€œtapped the chat button,â€ or â€œadded to favoritesâ€ accumulate into valuableÂ data.

This data helps us improve user experience and drives product decisions. For example, if we notice that users rarely tap the chat button, we might consider repositioning it to make it more visible. Instead of relying on gut feelings, we can make informed decisions backed byÂ data.

But collecting and analyzing this behavioral data turned out to be more complex than expected. As our log volume grew, we gradually hit the limitations of our operational approach.

Before diving into those challenges, let me briefly explain how we collect user events atÂ Karrot.

1.1. How We Collect UserÂ Events

As Karrot grew, so did the variety and volume of data we needed to collect. Our existing approach couldnâ€™t scale well or stay user-friendly, so we built our own user event loggingÂ system.

Hereâ€™s a simplified overview of how user events flow from generation to becoming analyzable data:

The process breaks down into three main stages: event collection, validation and processing, andÂ storage.

  1. Event Collection: When a user action occurs in the Karrot mobile app, the SDK sends data to our event server (managed by the Data team) based on specific conditions or intervals.
  2. Initial Validation and Routing: The event server performs basic validation, then forwards events to GCPÂ Pub/Sub.
  3. Stream Processing and Transformation: GCP Dataflow handles real-time validation of key fields, short-window deduplication, and data flattening.
  4. Storage and Error Handling: Throughout the pipeline, data is stored in GCS and BigQuery. Invalid events are routed to a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) Pub/Sub and stored in a separate BigQuery table for later analysis and debugging.
  5. Batch Deduplication: A subsequent batch job performs another round of time-window-based deduplication to improve data accuracy.
  6. Final Data Loading: Data is loaded into a format that team members can query directly. Common fields are stored in a flattened structure for immediate access, while event-specific parameters are stored as JSON for flexibility.

1.2. User EventÂ Schema

Once data reaches BigQuery, proper interpretation becomes essential for meaningful analysis.

Thatâ€™s where user event schemas come in. A schema defines what each log means and what fields it containsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe event type, expected parameters, and dataÂ formats.

Hereâ€™s why schemasÂ matter:

  1. They identify who owns each event.
    With hundreds of events generated across the company, it can be unclear whoâ€™s responsible for each one. Without knowing who created and maintains an event, operations become difficult. So we assign an owner to eachÂ event.
  2. They enable domain-based event classification.
    As our service grew, we needed to organize events systematically. For company-wide analysis, you might want to filter events related to specific domain only. To support this, we define a domain for eachÂ event.
  3. They allow custom parameters per event.
    All events share common fields like event_name, timestamp, and event_id. But each event also has unique informationâ€Šâ€”â€Šcustom parameters. Without documentation of what these parameters mean and their types, writing queries becomes confusing. You end up constantly checking whether a value is a string or number, or what the exact field nameÂ is.

Once you add an event schema, BigQuery automatically creates a table for that event. Custom parameters that were previously stored as JSON are now exposed as regular columns, making SQL queries muchÂ simpler:

SELECT 
  event_id,     -- common field
  event_name,   -- common field
  user_id,      -- common field
  banner_id,    -- custom parameter
  banner_title  -- custom parameter
FROM `event_dataset.event_name`

No more complex queries to extract values from JSONâ€Šâ€”â€Šcustom parameters like banner_id are directly queryable, making analysis muchÂ easier.

2. Before: Managing Event Schemas with Git-Based Code

User event schemas are a critical system for making collected data analyzable. Theyâ€™re primarily used to define team-specific custom fields and manage ownership, beyond the common loggingÂ fields.

These schemas need to be managed easily but consistently by anyone who wants to analyze data. But at the time, Karrot managed schemas through Git-based code. Without standardized event naming conventions, we started experiencing various operational challenges.

2.1. TheÂ Problems

Managing schemas in code without standardized event names led to multiple challenges. The biggest issue was that adding a single schema required way too muchÂ effort.

Problem 1: Complexity of Code-Based Schema Management

Creating a schema required this multi-step process:

  1. Write a JSON schema file in the data pipeline codebase (requires coding knowledge)
  2. Pass validation and formatting CIÂ checks
  3. Create aÂ PR
  4. Go through review cycles with the DataÂ team
  5. Once the PR is merged, a queryable BigQuery schema is auto-generated

The schema file in step 1 had to be written manually in Sparkâ€™s StructType JSONÂ format:

// client_{action_type}_{service}_{object}.json
{
  "type": "struct",
  "metadata": {
    "description": "Item click event",
    "owners": ["data@daangn.com"],
    "domains": ["data"]
  },
  "fields": [
    {
      "name": "id",
      "type": "string",
      "nullable": false,
      "metadata": {
        "comment": "Event ID"
      }
    }
  ]
}

Since schemas supported nested structures, they could get quiteÂ complex:

{
  "name": "extra",
  "type": {
    "type": "struct",
    "fields": [
      {
        "name": "random",
        "type": {
          "type": "struct",
          "fields": [
            {
              "name": "parent_item_id",
              "type": "string",
              "nullable": true,
              "metadata": {
                "comment": "Parent item ID"
              }
            }
          ]
        }
      }
    ]
  }
}

Step 1 was overly complicated. Even adding a simple field meant filling out metadata, nullable, type, and other attributes. Typos and formatting mistakes wereÂ common.

With deeply nested struct structures, missing a single bracket or comma would failÂ CI.

Problem 2: Long ReviewÂ Cycles

Other teams had to write JSON and submit PRs, which required Data team review. Convention violations, type errors, insufficient descriptionsâ€Šâ€”â€Švarious issues would trigger revision requests, leading to back-and-forth cycles that ate up significant time.

Problem 3: Inconsistent EventÂ Naming

Without enforced naming conventions, event names ended up in variousÂ formats:

Example 1: Same service, different casing

  • home_feed vs homeFeed (snake_case vs camelCase)

Example 2: Same action, different words

  • show_article vs shown_article
  • view vsÂ shown
Problem 4: Screen Name Confusion and Management Difficulties

Different teams called the same screen by different names. Some named screens based on functionality, others based on product specs. Without a unified standard, consistency gradually broke down. Screen information was scattered across team-specific Notion pages and separate documents.

This structure affected not just engineers working directly with event schemas, but also various roles that relied on logs. Hereâ€™s a summary of the difficulties each role experienced:

Schemas managed in code without a unified event system slowed down the entire workflow beyond just one teamâ€™s inconvenience.

2.2. The Solutions

To address these challenges, the Data team set a few key directions:

1. Establish a standardized user event system company-wide.

We decided to unify the different event naming conventions across teams into a common languageâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot team-specific jargon, but a common language everyone could use. We believed a consistent standard was necessary before logs could become company-wide assets.

So we standardized all event names. Now when someone mentions â€œchat button click on the fleamarket listing detail screen,â€ thereâ€™s no ambiguityâ€Šâ€”â€Ševeryone knows exactly what event that is. This reduces communication overhead and makes data discovery muchÂ faster.

2. Build an admin platform for defining user event schemas via UI instead ofÂ code.

We determined that code-based schema management, limited to certain teams and roles, had inherent limitations. So we decided to build an admin platform where anyone could define schemas directly through a UI. The system would automatically generate event names and formats according to conventions, maintaining consistency automatically.

Once you register a screen in the admin, you can see all events occurring on that screen in one place. Wondering â€œwhat events exist on the fleamarket listing detail screen?â€ Now anyoneâ€Šâ€”â€Šregardless of team or roleâ€Šâ€”â€Šcan look it up instantly.

3. Create a CLI that safely converts user event schemas to typed code for each programming language.

Define schemas in one placeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEvent Center, and the CLI automatically generates platform-specific code for IOS, Android, and Webview. This catches common errors like missing fields or type mismatches at compileÂ time.

3. Step One: Company-Wide Event SystemÂ Overhaul

To solve these problems, we first established a company-wide consistent event system. We decided that just changing tools while leaving different team rules in place wouldnâ€™t be a fundamental fix. To create consistency across teams, we built the following event naming convention:

1. User event must follow a three-level hierarchy: Service â†’ Screen â†’ ActionÂ (Event).
  • Service: The top-level unit representing the businessÂ domain.
  • Screen: Belongs to a service. Represents each screen the userÂ sees.
  • Event: Belongs to a screen. Represents user actions on thatÂ screen.
2. User event name must follow the format: client_{action}_{service}_{screen}_{object}
  • Actions are defined in pastÂ tense.
  • Elements are separated by snake_case, and individual elements use camelCase.

In practice, we also defined separate conventions for UI elements like bottomsheets and dialogs, but Iâ€™ll keep this overview focused on the core concepts.

With this naming convention, you can now tell which service and screen an event belongs to just by looking at itsÂ name.

4. Step Two: Event Centerâ€Šâ€”â€ŠUser Events Management Platform

After establishing a company-wide user event system, we needed a tool that would make it easy to define events following these rules. Having standards is pointless if defining and managing events remains difficult.

So we developed a log management system for systematically managing user events. Let me walk you through eachÂ step.

4.1. Service Management

You can view and manage all company servicesâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach service represents a product domain within Karrot, like Payment or Jobs. Events are organized byÂ service.

4.2. Screen Management

As mentioned earlier, different teams called the same screen by different names, and documentation was scattered, making it hard to understand what events belong to each screen. To solve this, we built functionality to register and manageÂ screens.

Once you register a screen, you can add the events that occur on it. Now all events for that screen are visible in oneÂ place.

4.3. Defining UserÂ Events

Select the screen where you want to add logging, then register and manage event schemas using a consistent log structure.

Throughout this process, you donâ€™t need to know anything about Spark StructType or JSON schemas. The system automatically handles:

  • Applying naming conventions
  • Generating Spark StructType JSON-based schemas
  • All validation checks that used to require reviews andÂ CI
  • BigQuery View TableÂ creation

Now anyone can register user event schemas with just a few clicks. Automated review processes have significantly improved time efficiency.

4.4. QA for UserÂ Events

After implementing logging, developers often wonder â€œis this actually being collected properly?â€ In Event Center, internal team members can query logs they generated using their own userÂ ID.

Hereâ€™s how the QA processÂ works:

  1. Developer implements logging code and performs the action on theirÂ device.
  2. In Event Center, search by your ID to view events you just triggered in near real-time, or check events from a specific timeÂ period.
  3. Immediately verify whether the event was collected correctly and parameters contain expectedÂ values.

No need to run BigQuery queries directly or check the app manually. Questions like â€œis item_id being captured correctly?" get instantÂ answers.

5. Type-Safe Code Generation viaÂ CLI

Once you define an event in Event Center, developers can auto-generate type-safe code using the CLI. With help from the Mobile team, we developed CLIs for each platform:

  • iOS: Generates SwiftÂ types
  • Android: Generates KotlinÂ types
  • Webview: Generates TypeScript interfaces

Webview TypeScript Code Generation Example

The CLI transforms Spark StructType JSON schemas into TypeScript:

// package.json
{
  "scripts": {
    "codegen": "event-center-codegen generate"
  }
}

// Usage
pnpm codegen

Auto-generated code

Developers simply use the generated types. If a field name is misspelled, it triggers a compile error. Logging is now safer with IDE autocomplete and type checking.

Wrapping Up

Iâ€™ve introduced you to Event Center, the log management system our team built to systematically manage user events. Event Center isnâ€™t a tool born from one teamâ€™s idea â€”itâ€™s the result of collaboration across multiple teams and roles. We shared our pain points and aligned our perspectives throughout the designÂ process.

Data analysts defined the consistent event system and helped establish standards for key screens and user events. Data engineers built reliable pipelines and ensured data quality. As a frontend engineer, I created the user-friendly admin interface and the CLI to improve developer experience.

When rolling out Event Center, we worked closely with the Mobile team and developers across teams. Together, we unified previously scattered event definitions into a single system and reorganized everything by screen. This migration brought our company-wide event system to production.â€

Event Center isnâ€™t just one teamâ€™s toolâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s an attempt to collectively change how we handle user events atÂ Karrot.

That said, challenges remain. While Event Center solved many problems, itâ€™s not a perfect solution. As people started using it, we discovered new areas toÂ improve.

User Experience Improvements

  • Adding an event still requires multiple clicks and inputs. We need faster, simplerÂ methods.
  • Currently, only single screens can be registered, so when UI varies based on success/failure states, each state needs its own screen. This needs improvement too.

Taking Automation Further

  • We still have limitations in pinpointing exactly which UI element triggered an event on a givenÂ screen.
  • What if we could integrate with Figma to define events at the design stage and auto-generate code? We want to create an environment where designers, PMs, and engineers can discuss events while looking at the sameÂ screen.

Analytics Tool Extensions

  • Weâ€™re considering automatic calculation of basic metrics like CTR, PV, and AU from logged data, and UI-based experiment metric configuration. The goal is to move beyond just collecting logs to enabling immediate decision-making.

We plan to tackle these challenges one by one as Event Center continues toÂ evolve.

This year, the Data team is taking another step toward our visionâ€Šâ€”â€Šmaking data-driven decisions for users every day. Event Center was one effort along thatÂ journey.

Our team is working to improve everything from how we collect logs to how we interpret and leverage data. Interested in this work? If you want to be part of building systems that turn data into better products and decisions, weâ€™d love to chat. Check out our open positions below:

  • Data Analytics Engineer
  • Software Engineer

item.title: Standardizing User Activation: How We Built a Shared Data Layer at Karrot
item.content:encoded:
Hello, Iâ€™m Pepper, a Data Analytics Engineer on the Data Team atÂ Karrot.

Our team's vision is to "make user-focused decisions through data every day." So we don't just focus on reliably collecting massive amounts of dataâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe also work on transforming it into trustworthy, easy-to-use formats.

In this post, I'd like to share how we moved away from manually calculating Activation analysis with ad hoc queries and elevated it to a shared data layer used across the organization.

Background

The Limits of Active UserÂ Metrics

Like many services, Active Users (DAU, WAU, MAU) are essential metrics at Karrot. But the number of Active Users only shows "what happened"â€Šâ€”â€Šit doesn't directly explain "why it happened." For example, you can see that "MAU increased by 10% this month," but it's hard to answer questions such as why Active Users changed or what we should do to increase themÂ further.

To answer these questions, we need a perspective that doesn't treat Active Users as a single number but breaks them down into components with distinct characteristics. That's precisely what User Activation does.

User Activation: Activity States and State Transitions

User Activation is a framework that goes beyond simply classifying users as active or inactive. It examines usersâ€™ current activity state and how they transition between states overÂ time.

  • Activity states indicate a user's state at a specific point in time. For example, states like New, Retained, Reactivated, and Inactive.
  • State transitions represent how users move between activity states over time. For example, transitions like New â†’ Retained, Retained â†’ Inactive, or Reactivated â†’ Inactive.

Activity states alone can tell you "how many users are in each state right now," but they can't reveal "where they came from" or "what paths lead to churn." By looking at state transitions together, you can understand the paths users take. Segmenting users by these transition patterns enables tailored interpretations and actions across activityÂ levels.

For example, when the number of Active Users increases, you can use activity states to decompose and explain whether the growth came from new user acquisition or returning existing users. If retention rate drops, you can use state transitions to pinpoint which specific segment is churning more, rather than just concluding "retention rate gotÂ worse."

Goals

Why We Needed a CommonÂ Layer

To analyze user behavior through the lens of User Activation, you need data that already includes each user's activity state and how that state changes over time. The challenge was that when each team defined and maintained this logic independently, it was difficult to maintain reliable data and a stable pipeline. Team-created data often lacked context about who created it, when, and with what criteriaâ€Šâ€”â€Šmaking it hard to understand or verify results over time. Operational issues, such as failed scheduled queries or reprocessing, sometimes broke idempotency or left data without freshness guarantees. Ultimately, the data existed, but it was often difficult to use with confidence.

We decided to build an Activation Layerâ€”a common layer that applies Activation in accordance with unified, organization-level standards. Our goal was to ensure the reliability and operational stability of results while enabling multiple teams to reuse the same standards.

User Activation is a framework for interpreting Active User metrics through states and transitions. The Activation Layer is a common data layer that provides per-user state and transition information needed for interpretation, following consistent standards.

What We Wanted the Activation Layer toÂ Do

After deciding to build the Activation Layer as a shared common layer, our first task was defining "what this layer should provide." By organizing the recurring questions within our company, we identified the following specific information needs:

  • Whether the current activity is New, Retained, or Reactivated (activity state)
  • How the state changed from the previous period to the current period (state transition)
  • Whether recent activity has been continuous (continuity)
  • How long since the last activity before returning (return interval)
  • How long since the previous active state (inactivity duration)

For example, if a user visited on December 10, December 11, and December 20, we should provide the above information at the daily level, asÂ shown.

user_A (daily)
- 2025â€“12â€“10 NEW
- 2025â€“12â€“11 RETAINED (prev=2025â€“12â€“10, interval=1d)
- 2025â€“12â€“20 REACTIVATED (prev=2025â€“12â€“111,11interval=9d)

While we used visits as an example here, User Activation applies not only to app visits but also to core actions such as selling used items, writing community posts, or opening push notifications.

Three Challenges We Solved While Designing the Activation Layer

Now, let me walk you through how we implemented the Activation Layer. First, here's an overview of the overall structure.

Overall Structure at aÂ Glance

We designed the Activation Layer to sit on top of Karrot's existing DBT project data hierarchy. Instead of using raw event logs directly, we built it in the order of Base (refined) â†’ Fact (action unit) â†’ Activation (state/flow analysis).

For more details about Karrot's data hierarchy structure, please refer to our post "7 Problems We Faced While Adopting DBT and Airflow."

We built the Activation Layer so that three modelsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠFirstLast, Activation, and Activation Statusâ€Šâ€”â€Šwork together as a set on top of a single Fact model. I'll explain what each model contains, what role it plays, and how they connectÂ later.

While building this structure, we faced three main challenges: reliability, cost, and productivity. Let me explain how we solved eachÂ one.

1. Reliability: Clearly Fixing the Reference Action

First, if we want to run Activation as a shared layer, we need an explicit reference action. If teams interpret the criteria differently, no one can reuse the data without revalidating it each time. We prioritized making the reference action obvious at a glanceâ€”just by looking at the model name and definition.

At first, we tried to map event logs 1:1 to Activation reference actions. But product teams usually log events at the UI levelâ€Šâ€”â€Šbutton clicks, screen viewsâ€Šâ€”â€Šso a single event can represent different actions depending on its parameters. For example, one "interest button click" event can cover both adding and removing interest. If we used "interest added" as the reference action, we would have to keep filtering for the "add" case every time we queriedÂ it.

Instead of using event logs directly as reference actions, we should fix the reference actions themselves to be precise units. Karrot uses DBT for data modeling and manages models with a conceptual distinction calledÂ Layers.

Among them, the Fact Layer defines user actions. It expresses meaningful action units, ranging from simple actions (e.g., "user sent a message") to actions that require conditions and business logic (e.g., "user actively used theÂ feed").

We decided to define reference actions as Fact models and implement the Activation Layer to use them as inputs. To make reference actions even more visible at a glance, we established a naming convention where Activation model names include the Fact modelÂ name.

# Naming convention
<fact_name>_activation_<time_grain>
# fact_name: Same as Fact Layer model name (action meaning defined in Fact)
# time_grain: daily | weekly | monthly
# Examples
users_visited_app_activation_daily
users_opened_push_activation_daily
users_created_article_activation_daily

As a result, Activation models now clearly indicate the reference action from the model name alone, reducing the room for interpretation to vary based on event parameters or filter conditions.

2. Cost: Making It Sustainable

To calculate Activation, we need to track two timestamps per user: the first occurrence and the previous occurrence. Even if users are active on the same day, their Activation state can differ depending on when they last acted. For example, someone who visits on December 20 may be classified as Retained or Reactivated, depending on whether they last visited on December 19 or DecemberÂ 11.

The problem is that if there's no pre-calculated table for these values, you have to scan the entire Fact model to find the previous occurrence. In a service environment with large data volumes, such as Karrot, scan range directly impacts cost and execution timeâ€Šâ€”â€Šthis was the most significant cost hurdle in operating Activation.

Therefore, we introduced an intermediate table, FirstLast, to reduce compute costs. At the same time, the storage strategy for FirstLast significantly affects both daily run costs and backfill costs, so we compared three approaches.

Candidate 1â€Šâ€”â€ŠCalculate directly from Fact eachÂ time

This approach doesn't use an intermediate table and scans the entire history each time to get User Activation. The structure is simplest, but it requires scanning the whole Fact model history on every execution, resulting in high daily costs and increased execution time. We ruled this out due to the operational burden of repeatedÂ runs.

Candidate 2â€Šâ€”â€ŠKeep only the latest value perÂ user

This approach stores the first and last occurrence in a single record per user. The first occurrence rarely changes once it's set. The most recent occurrence, however, needs daily updates. Since we only merge users who acted today, each daily run scans just one day of the Fact table. However, because it doesn't store historical last occurrences separately, backfills still require scanning the entire Fact modelÂ range.

Candidate 3â€Šâ€”â€ŠMaintain daily snapshots âœ…

This approach stores each user's previous occurrences as a daily snapshot. To build today's snapshot, we start from yesterday's snapshot, update users who were active today, and carry forward the previous values for users who weren't. As a result, both the intermediate table update and the Activation calculation only need one day of data. That allows us to keep the scan range fixed to a single day for both daily runs and backfills.

In conclusion, we selected Candidate 3 for the FirstLast model because backfills occur periodically at Karrot, and this approach minimizes scan volume even during backfills.

Of course, the snapshot approach has trade-offs too. It increases storage costs as daily snapshots accumulate, and issues on a specific date can cascade to subsequent dates. However, because backfills only need to reload affected partitions, we found this approach more cost-effective and faster than Option 2, which requires full scans. Also, through data quality monitoring, we could detect issues before they spread and respondÂ quickly.

3. Productivity: Creating Models for New Actions WithoutÂ SQL

The next challenge we faced was "how can we easily create Activation models for any action?" Activation calculations involve complex logic, such as WINDOW functions, JOINs, and CASE statements. Writing SQL directly each time led to slightly different implementations, resulting in inconsistent schemas.

We encapsulated the calculation logic in DBT macros. New Activation models can now be created by just specifying the reference Fact modelÂ name.

[Before] Implementing Activation logic directly inÂ SQL

-- Partial query to get the user's first action time and previous action for the monthly activity state

WITH first_activation AS (
    SELECT user_id, MIN(event_date) as first_date
    FROM events
    WHERE â€¦
    GROUP BY user_id
),

monthly_activity AS (
    SELECT
    user_id,
    DATE_TRUNC('month', event_date) as month,
    LAG(DATE_TRUNC('month', event_date)) OVER (
    PARTITION BY user_id ORDER BY event_date
    ) as prev_month
    FROM events
    WHERE â€¦
),

â€¦ (window functions, joins, CASE branches, etc.)

[After] Creating models without writing SQL using DBTÂ Macros

Final Results

To capture the information needed for Activation analysis while meeting the reliability, cost, and productivity as mentioned above, we designed the Activation Layer so that three models operate as a set based on a single FactÂ model.

  • FirstLast aggregates each user's first/last action timestamps into daily snapshots to improve cost efficiency.
  • Activation takes the Fact model and FirstLast model as inputs, produces New/Retained/Reactivated states and return intervals for dates with activity, and returns the intervals.
  • Activation Status includes inactive users to provide state transitions, continuity, and inactivity duration for allÂ dates.

These three models are connected sequentially to build the states and flows required for Activation analysis progressively.

Three-Model Structure and DataÂ Examples

To quickly understand each model's data composition and how it works, let's walk through an example: User A visits for the first time on December 10 and then returns on December 11 and DecemberÂ 20.

1. FirstLast Model

FirstLast is an intermediate model that stores each user's first/last action timestamps as daily snapshots. Every day, it fetches the previous day's snapshot, updates the last active date for users with activity today, and carries forward the previous day's values for users without activity to generate snapshots for allÂ users.

For User A, on their first visit on December 10, we set both the first active date and last active date to December 10. When they return on December 11, we update only the last active date. From December 12 to 19, the user doesn't visit, but we still generate a daily snapshot. When they visit again on December 20, we set the last active date to thatÂ date.

Thanks to these snapshots, Activation calculations can get the previous timestamp by just referencing the previous day's snapshot.

2. Activation Model

This model keeps only dates with activity based on the Fact model. It references the FirstLast model to retrieve the previous activity timestamp, and based on this, calculates New/Retained/Reactivated states and return intervals. It also aggregates information, such as action counts for eachÂ date.

For User A, on December 10, there's no prior record in FirstLast, so they're classified as a new user. On December 11, it retrieves the last active date (December 10) from the December 10 snapshot in FirstLast and uses it as the previous active date. Since the return interval between the active date and the previous active date is 1 day, the user is classified as retained. From December 12 to 19, when there's no activity, no rows are generated in the Activation model.

The Activation model can be used to decompose the number of Active Users into activity-state components (New/Retained/Reactivated) and analyze month-over-month contributions.

3. Activation StatusÂ Model

Unlike the Activation model, this model fills in inactive periods to provide states for all dates. It provides not only the inactivity duration and consecutive active days but also transition segments that show how statesÂ changed.

Transition segments are values that further segment user flows by combining "previous activity state â†’ current activity state." For example, users in the same Retained state are distinguished as New User Retained (New â†’ Retained), Core User Retained (Retained â†’ Retained), or Reactivated User Retained (Reactivated â†’ Retained). Similarly, churned users are segmented as Core User Churned (Retained â†’ Inactive), Reactivation Failed (Reactivated â†’ Inactive), etc.

For User A, they start in the New state on December 10, become active on December 11, and transition to the Retained state; therefore, the transition segment is New User Retained. From December 12 to 19, there's no activity, but we can see the inactivity duration. On December 20, the activity state detail shows they returned after 8Â days.

The Activation Status model enables more sophisticated analysis of acquisition-churn-return flows by combining activity states with previous states through transition segments.

Use Cases

1. AU Dashboard and AnalysisÂ Agent

As mentioned in the background, the number of Active Users alone doesn't immediately tell you "why it increased or decreased." This chart breaks down changes in Active Users relative to the previous period into New/Retained/Reactivated contributions, enabling quick identification of the causes ofÂ change.

1) AU Compositionâ€Šâ€”â€ŠContribution by ActivityÂ State

For example, MAU of November is -1.20%p compared to October, mainly due to decreased Reactivated users (-0.90%p) and Retained users (-0.35%p), partially offset by New users (+0.05%p).

As shown in the example below, we quickly assess the MAU change drivers through user group contributions.

2) Seeing Where Users Flowedâ€Šâ€”â€ŠTransition SegmentÂ Analysis

Looking only at activity states tells us how much each segment grew or shrank this month, but it doesn't tell us how those changes happened. When Active Users move, knowing the paths they tookâ€”where they came from and where they wentâ€”helps us decide what to doÂ next.

We use a transition segment in the Activation Status model to break down state transitions and quickly identify which flows changed, even for exact stateÂ changes.

For example, both September and November 2025 have 220 retained users (activation_status = retained). Looking only at activity states, the retained users for both months appear the same. But when broken down by transition segment, "Retained New User (New â†’ Retained)" decreased from 100 in September to 50 in November. It means that while overall retained user volume is the same, new user retention is weakeningâ€”a signal we can catch. In such cases, there's a high likelihood we need to examine the onboarding funnel or early experience.

Furthermore, we also provide an analysis Agent that supplies dashboard interpretation guides as prompts. It enables team members to gain a range of insights through conversations with the Agent on our internal LLM platform.

2. Marketing Targeting and Performance Analysis

The Activation model we built is now also being used for the Marketing team's performance analysis. For example, when executing CRM actions, we define targets based on the Activation Layer. We segment audiences by inactivity duration, like users churned for 3+ months, and can now analyze campaign performance using the same criteria.

3. Core Action Tracking byÂ Service

Each team can now define important core actions as Activation models and track them. Instead of just looking at DAU for that action, they can view activity state composition and day-over-day churn rate together to monitor user flows. It enables teams to identify changes that might be missed when reviewing individual experiment metrics, from the perspective of overall user composition changes within strategic decisions.

Conclusion

The biggest realization from building the Activation Layer was that well-structured data alone can transform team-wide productivity. Time spent writing complex SQL queries repeatedly decreased, and teams needing growth analysis can now make decisions based on the data directly.

Also, the Activation Layer wasn't just about creating a table that calculates AUâ€”it was an attempt to establish a common language for interpreting user behavior across states and flows. Especially in today's environment, as LLM-powered analysis grows, I believe providing structured data that LLMs can understand is more important than giving massive raw datasets. We plan to continue creating such structured data in theÂ future.

As such, Karrot's Data Team works on making data trustworthy and easy for anyone to use. Among them, Data Analytics Engineers design structures that enable analysts, engineers, and product teams to consistently leverage data without complex queries, spanning data modeling, pipeline design, and metric definition. If this post sparked your interest in data structuring and modeling, please check out the job postingsÂ below!

item.title: Karrotâ€™s Generative AI Platform
item.content:encoded:
When we first shared Using LLMs at Karrot in early 2024, we were just beginning our journey with large languageÂ models.

A year and a half later, the landscape has transformed dramatically. AI models have advanced beyond what we could have imagined, and Karrot has scaled to hundreds of GenAI use cases across products and data pipelines.

In this post, weâ€™ll share the challenges we encountered while scaling GenAI adoption and the platforms we built to address them. We hope our learnings help others navigating similarÂ paths.

Platform Overview

GenAI powers services across Karrotâ€™s entire stackâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrom user-facing features to internal data pipelines. Behind the scenes, three core platforms enable this adoption.

While the architecture may seem complex at first glance, LLM Router, Prompt Studio, and KarrotChat each evolved to solve distinct problems. Letâ€™s dive into what each platform addresses and how we builtÂ them.

LLM Router

The Account Management Problem

In the early days of LLM adoption, teams provisioned their own accounts and API keys whenever they needed AI capabilities. With models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and others, accounts and keys proliferated rapidlyâ€Šâ€”â€Šand so did the management overhead. Several pain pointsÂ emerged:

Provisioning became a bottleneck. As more teams adopted AI, the account and API key setup process itself became a friction point. With numerous keys in circulation, tracking which team used which credentials for what service became increasingly difficult, raising security concerns.

Rate limits created uneven availability. AI APIs typically enforce per-account rate limits. With teams operating independently, some accounts had plenty of headroom while others hit their limits, causing request failures.

Cost visibility was fragmented. As accounts and keys multiplied, aggregating usage and costs required querying multiple sources. Getting a unified view of Karrotâ€™s total AI spend became time-consuming.

Unifying Through an APIÂ Gateway

We built LLM Router to solve these challenges. The core concept: funnel all AI API calls through a single gateway. API keys and accounts are managed centrally by LLM Router, while individual services authenticate with just a service IDâ€Šâ€”â€Šno separate credentials required.

This unlocked several improvements:

Eliminated provisioning overhead. The account and API key setup process disappeared entirely. We recalled most previously issued keys (with a few exceptions), and teams can now access any supported API immediately.

Centralized operations. With all traffic flowing through one point, our infrastructure team took over unified account management. Rate limit monitoring and quota adjustments became their responsibility, freeing product teams to focus on building features.

Unified cost visibility. Every request through LLM Router is attributed to its originating service. This data feeds into Karrotâ€™s infrastructure cost management platform, providing at-a-glance visibility into which services consume which modelsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand at whatÂ cost.

One Interface, EveryÂ Model

For LLM Router to serve as the universal gateway, it needed to support OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, and even models we self-host via vLLM. The challenge: each provider has different API formats and capabilities. Without abstraction, client code would need changes every time we switchedÂ models.

We standardized on the OpenAI interface. All modelsâ€Šâ€”â€Šregardless of providerâ€Šâ€”â€Šare accessible through the OpenAI SDK. Whether youâ€™re calling `claude-4.5-sonnet` or `gpt-5.2`, you simply change the model name. LLM Router handles provider-specific translation internally. When new models launch, we add them to LLM Router once. Teams can immediately use them by specifying the new model nameâ€Šâ€”â€Šzero code changes required.

from openai import OpenAI

client = OpenAI(base_url="https://llm_router") # Point to LLM Router
completion = client.chat.completions.create(
 model="claude-4.5-sonnet", # Any supported model
 messages=[
 {"role": "user", "content": "Hello!"}
 ]
)

Prompt Studio

The Experimentation Bottleneck

Early in our LLM journey, building AI-powered features always required code. Validating an ideaâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œCan this prompt solve this problem?â€â€Šâ€”â€Šmeant first requesting engineering support. How well an approach works, how to craft the prompt, which model fits bestâ€Šâ€”â€Šthese vary by use case and require iterative experimentation. When every iteration required an engineer, rapid experimentation wasnâ€™t possible.

No-Code AI Feature Development

Prompt Studio is the web-based platform we built to solve this. Anyone can create and test AI features without writing code. Enter a prompt, select a model, click run. If results donâ€™t match expectations, revise and run againâ€Šâ€”â€Šiterating toward the desired behavior.

The platform supports all models from OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic, plus internally-hosted models. Switch freely between them to compare outputs and find the best fit. This enabled PMs and other non-engineering roles to build AI features independently, iterating as fast as theyÂ needed.

Once a prompt shows promise, it needs systematic evaluation. A few successful examples donâ€™t guarantee consistent quality across diverse inputs. Prompt Studioâ€™s Evaluation feature lets you upload test setsâ€Šâ€”â€Šhundreds to thousands of examplesâ€Šâ€”â€Šgenerate results in batch, and measure performance quantitatively. This answers: â€œHow well does this prompt perform across varied scenarios?â€

When a prompt is production-ready, deployment is straightforward. Engineers integrate the Prompt Studio API only once. After that, teams ship prompt improvements directly from the UIâ€Šâ€”â€Šno code changes needed. Multiple versions live within a single project, making it easy to compare iterations and roll back if needed. Selecting which version serves production traffic is a singleÂ click.

This architecture enables anyone to own AI features end-to-endâ€Šâ€”â€Šcontinuously testing and improving without engineering dependencies. Features like AI Writing Assistance shipped quickly through Prompt Studio and continue toÂ evolve.

Prompt Studio has become the repository of AI knowledge across Karrot. Teams can reference how others structure their prompts, and best practices naturally accumulate. Itâ€™s evolved into the central hub where our collective AI expertise lives.

Building Reliable AIÂ APIs

One challenge we faced: ensuring high availability when depending on external AI services. Rate limits, latency spikes, and occasional service disruptions can affect any cloud API. When a critical feature depends on a single model, any service interruption impacts that feature directly.

Handling reliability per-feature is costly and inconsistent. Prompt Studio provides multiple layers of resilience:

Retry: Transient failures trigger automatic retries with exponential backoff.

Region Fallback: When rate limits or errors hit in one region, requests automatically retry against the same model in a different region. If `gemini-2.5-flash` in `us-central1` fails, we retry in the `global`Â region.

Model Fallback: When all retries fail, requests fall back to a pre-configured alternative model from a different provider. If Googleâ€™s `gemini-2.5-flash` is unavailable even across regions, we route to OpenAIâ€™sÂ GPT-5.

Circuit Breaker: During sustained outagesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhen a model continuously failsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe circuit breaker activates. The system blocks requests to that model immediately, routing directly to fallback. It periodically health-checks the blocked model and restores traffic when it recovers. This fail-fast pattern minimizes latency during sustained providerÂ outages.

These layered safeguards ensure AI-powered services remain operational even when individual providers experience issues.

Beyond Text Generation

AI capabilities now extend well beyond text. Models like OpenAIâ€™s GPT-Image and Sora, along with Googleâ€™s NanoBanana, generate images and video with remarkable quality. Teams use these generation models through the same Prompt Studio workflow: select a model, test prompts, deploy whenÂ ready.

This unified approach enables diverse GenAI applications. We rapidly prototyped and launched campaigns and features like Karrot AI Photo Studio, Dream Home, and AI Try-on through PromptÂ Studio.

Agents and the MCP Ecosystem

Interest in AI Agentsâ€Šâ€”â€Šsystems that use tools and execute multi-step workflowsâ€Šâ€”â€Šis growing rapidly. Agents receive a task along with available tools, then autonomously select and invoke tools as needed. The capabilities are bounded only by the tools youÂ provide.

Building effective Agents requires two things: well-designed tools and an execution loop that orchestrates tool calls and AI reasoning until the task completes. Prompt Studio providesÂ both:

MCP Hub: A registry for discovering and sharing internally-developed MCPs (Model Context Protocol tools). Register a useful MCP, and anyone at Karrot can find and use it. The hub hosts tools for querying internal data, fetching documents, andÂ more.

Agent Builder: Combine tools from the MCP Hub to create Agents without code. Write task instructions, select a model and MCPs, and youâ€™re done. Prompt Studio handles the orchestration loop automatically and captures every Agent execution as a Traceâ€Šâ€”â€Šenabling step-by-step debugging: â€œWhy did the LLM call this tool?â€ â€œWhat was the tool response?â€

Agents you build in Prompt Studio become immediately available in KarrotChat.

KarrotChat

Our Internal AgentÂ Platform

Prompt Studio is where you build AI features and Agentsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠKarrotChat is where you useÂ them.

Through KarrotChat, teams can discover and interact with Agents from Prompt Studio. Users can also select any supported model for direct conversation, and enabling MCPs from the hub requires just a toggle. Useful conversations can be shared acrossÂ teams.

Case Study: DANAâ€Šâ€”â€ŠData AnalysisÂ Agent

What happens when tools that access internal data meet capable AI and domain expertise? Karrot accumulates rich analytical data in BigQuery. But actually performing analysis was challengingâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou needed to know which tables hold what information, what columns mean, which joins to perform, and how to write BigQuery SQL. This knowledge lived with a small group of specialists.

Prompt Studio let us connect MCPs with AI and capture data analysis expertise in Agent instructions. Now anyone can ask questions in KarrotChat and perform sophisticated analysis.

DANAâ€Šâ€”â€ŠData Analyst of NA Product teamâ€Šâ€”â€Šexemplifies this transformation. It combines the BigQuery MCP, detailed documentation of the data model, and carefully crafted prompts. Team members now get answers and insights without understanding the underlying schema.

Ask â€œGive me daily post counts for the past week,â€ and DANA finds the right table, runs the query, and returns the answer. For deeper questions like â€œWhich category was the most popular over the past 10 days?â€ it joins tables, aggregates data, and surfaces insights.

No SQL knowledge required. No schema expertise needed. Since launch, DANA has become part of the teamâ€™s daily workflowâ€Šâ€”â€Šhelping everyone make faster, more confident data-driven decisions.

Internal Agents like DANA are multiplying. Knowledge that once lived with specialists now spreads across the organization through Agentsâ€Šâ€”â€Šmeasurably boosting productivity acrossÂ teams.

Wrapping Up

Karrot has embraced AI across operations and services. Throughout 2025, weâ€™ve built numerous AI features and internal Agents, all running on this platform. With multiple services depending on shared infrastructure, we invest heavily in reliability, observability, and security.

Our GenAI platform evolved in alignment with Karrotâ€™s core values: autonomy, rapid experimentation, and transparent knowledge sharing. Teams adopt AI independently while the platform provides company-wide visibility and governance. Effective prompts and Agents naturally propagate across the organization. This cultural foundation has enabled Karrot to adapt quickly to the GenAIÂ era.

As adoption grows, so does responsibility. The platform now handles hundreds of millions of requestsâ€Šâ€”â€Šstability and security have never been more critical. AI technology advances daily, with new models and capabilities emerging constantly.

The LLM Infrastructure team work to bring these advances to the platform firstâ€Šâ€”â€Šso every product team at Karrot can build on them. Weâ€™re hiring engineers to help shape the future of AI infrastructure here. If that sounds interesting, weâ€™d love toÂ talk.

item.title: Running Elasticsearch on Kubernetes the Easy Way, Part 2â€Šâ€”â€ŠData Node Warm-Up
item.content:encoded:
Running Elasticsearch on Kubernetes the Easy Way, Part 2â€Šâ€”â€ŠData NodeÂ Warm-Up

Hi, weâ€™re Ellie and Jarry from the Search Platform team at Karrot. Our team is responsible for handling the massive search traffic generated across Karrotâ€™s various services-quickly and reliably-while building a platform that enables new search experiences. In Part 1, we shared our journey of migrating our search infrastructure to Kubernetes (ECK), achieving deployment automation and reducing deployment time. What once took 5 hours was cut down to 90 minutes, and anyone could now safely deploy to our search clusters.

At the end of Part 1, we mentioned the following:

â€œWhen deploying during peak traffic times, we observed spikes in CPU usage and latency. (â€¦) Since there are short-term solutions like simply avoiding peak hours for deployments, we decided to proceed while accepting this as a non-issue.â€

Back then, we thought, â€œJust avoid peak hours-no big deal.â€ But over time, we realized that the constraint of having to avoid peak hours was itself the problem. Operators still had to constantly watch the clock, and once a deployment started, they still had to nervously monitor dashboards. In this article, weâ€™ll explain why we came to see this as a problem and how we solvedÂ it.

1. Challenges Remaining After ECKÂ Adoption

1.1. How Much Has Our Search Infrastructure Grown in TwoÂ Years?

When we wrote Part 1, we had a single search cluster handling about 1,000 queries per second (1K QPS) atÂ peak.

Two years later, Karrot has grown and so has our search infrastructure. We now operate four clusters, each serving different purposes, with peak traffic likeÂ this:

As we explained in Part 1, our ECK-based search clusters operate using the following architecture: we define Elasticsearch Custom Resources in a Kubernetes environment and run them as StatefulSets.

It wasnâ€™t just traffic that increased. With four clusters now in operation, the operational burden grew as well. As covered in Part 1, deploying a single cluster took roughly 90 minutes. With four clusters, total deployment time stretched beyond 6 hours, and someone had to monitor the entireÂ process.

1.2. The Limits of â€œJust Deploy Outside PeakÂ Hoursâ€

In Part 1, we said we achieved deployment automation with ECK-but there was an important caveat: â€œas long as we avoid peakÂ hours.â€

At first, this didnâ€™t seem like a big deal. We could just deploy in the early morning or late at night. But as we scaled to four clusters and deployments became more frequent, the practical issues becameÂ clear.

First, the available deployment windows kept shrinking. After avoiding peak hours, lunch breaks, and the times right before and after work, only a few hours each day were left for deployments. Situations arose where urgent patches were blocked because â€œitâ€™s peak time rightÂ now.â€

Second, deployments started feeling like â€œbig events.â€ Before clicking the ArgoCD sync button, we had to check: â€œIs traffic okay right now? Is it safe to deploy at this hour?â€ Even during deployment, we had to keep watching the latency graphs. We wondered: if weâ€™ve automated deployments, why does it still feel so stressful?

Ultimately, the real problem we needed to solve wasÂ this:

â€œLetâ€™s create a state where we can deploy with peace of mind, whether itâ€™s peak time orÂ not.â€

So why were we so afraid of peakÂ hours?

It wasnâ€™t just because traffic was high. The real issue was the latency spikes that occurred during rolling restarts. Letâ€™s dig into the rootÂ causes.

2. The Real Reason Rolling Restarts WereÂ Scary

A Kubernetes StatefulSet rolling restart updates Pods one at a time, in order. As soon as a Pod becomes Ready, it moves on to theÂ next.

The problem is that for systems like Elasticsearch that rely heavily on caches, this approach isnâ€™t safe. A Pod being Ready doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s actually ready to handle trafficâ€Šâ€”â€Šfrequently accessed data must be loaded into memory (page cache, query cache, etc.) before the node can respondÂ quickly.

At Karrot, we actually experienced a major outage due to this issue during an ECK rolling restart. That incident became the starting point for building our warm-upÂ system.

2.1. A Real IncidentÂ Story

One day, an Elastic Operator version issue triggered a rolling restart across all Elasticsearch StatefulSets. For a typical Kubernetes service, Pods would go down and come back up one by one without muchÂ trouble.

But Elasticsearch was different. As the rolling restart progressed, the next Pod restarted as soon as the previous one became Ready, but from Elasticsearchâ€™s perspective, it wasnâ€™t actually ready. The restarted nodes had completely empty caches and had to serve traffic in a severely degraded state. During this process, some shards had both their primary and replica affected in succession, degrading availability, and ultimately causing a major outage across the searchÂ service.

This experience taught us that the expectation â€˜Kubernetes will handle rolling restarts safelyâ€™ does not apply to Elasticsearch.

2.2. What Happens When a Data NodeÂ Restarts

When a data node restarts, several things happen simultaneously inside Elasticsearch.

First, the restarted data node joins the Elasticsearch cluster with a completely empty file system cache. In this state, queries must read data from disk, significantly increasing searchÂ latency.

Second, while the data node is down, the load on that shard is concentrated on other replicaÂ shards.

The moment these two issues overlap is when the cluster is most unstable.

The Problem with Cacheâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCold NewÂ Nodes

Elasticsearch uses multiple levels of cachingâ€Šâ€”â€Špage cache, query cache, field data cache, request cache, and more. But when a data node starts fresh, all these caches are empty. Every cache miss requires reading segments from disk, and as this delay accumulates, requests start piling up in the search thread pool queue. The result: p50 and p90 latency can spike to several times their normalÂ values.

The Problem of Load Concentration on Remaining Nodes

When a data node goes down, the replica shards it held become Unassigned. The ES cluster transitions to a yellow state, meaning â€œall primary shards are alive, but some replicas are unassigned.â€ The service doesnâ€™t stop immediately, but two problemsÂ emerge:

  • The remaining replica shards must handle all requests, increasing theirÂ load.
  • Shards without replicas become a single point of failure. If the node holding that primary also dies, the cluster goes redâ€Šâ€”â€Šunable to process search or indexing requests.

In summary, request volume stays the same while the number of nodes available to handle it decreases, concentrating load on the remaining nodes. Then, when a cache-cold node rejoins, latency spikes for requests routed toÂ it.

When both of these problems occur together, rolling restarts in Elasticsearch become particularly scary.

3. Defining Goals and SolutionÂ Strategy

After analyzing the problem, we defined our targetÂ state:

â€œCreate a state where clicking the Elasticsearch deploy button at any time wonâ€™t bring down the search service.â€

Specifically, we wanted threeÂ things:

  • No need for humans to monitor and adjust timing during deployment
  • Search p99 latency stays under 1s even during rollingÂ restarts
  • The system handles unexpected node restarts automatically

3.1. Why Kubernetes Native Mechanisms Werenâ€™tÂ Enough

You might wonder: â€œCanâ€™t we just tweak readinessProbe or add a postStart hook for warm-up?â€ But due to how Elasticsearch works, these approaches donâ€™tÂ help.

The key is when Elasticsearch data node joins the cluster. As soon as a data node Pod enters Running state, it joins the Elasticsearch cluster. This happens completely independently of Kubernetes readinessProbe or postStart hooks. The moment the Elasticsearch process starts, it tells the master node â€œIâ€™m ready,â€ and the master immediately begins assigning shards to thisÂ node.

Even before the readinessProbe passes, the node is already part of the Elasticsearch cluster. Being removed from the Kubernetes Serviceâ€™s Endpoints doesnâ€™t matterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠElasticsearch uses its own node discovery and routing, sending requests directly to the node within the cluster, bypassing the Kubernetes Service. postStart hooks are similarâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe ES process can join the cluster before the hook completes; it doesnâ€™tÂ wait.

Fundamentally, neither Kubernetes nor Elasticsearch settings alone can automate the state of â€œdonâ€™t receive traffic until warm-up is complete.â€ So our solution strategy boils down to oneÂ line:

â€œLet nodes restart freely, but donâ€™t let them receive search traffic until warm-up is complete.â€

The implementation of this idea is our warm-up system, with search-coordinator as its core component. Weâ€™ll explain how it works in detail in the nextÂ section.

4. search-coordinator Proxy Architecture

Now letâ€™s look at how we made it possible to click the Elasticsearch deploy button withoutÂ worry.

The core idea is simple: we placed a proxy called search-coordinator between our servers and Elasticsearch, creating a structure where only warmed-up data nodes participate in search. Thanks to this architecture, even when data nodes restart, search traffic always flows only to nodes that have completed warm-up.

4.1. Architecture Overview

Previously, services connected directly to Elasticsearch, giving us no control over traffic. Now, all requests go through search-coordinator, giving us traffic control. We operate one ECK cluster and one search-coordinator per namespace in a 1:1 structure. We added the search-coordinator module to the existing ECK-only architecture as shownÂ below:

search-coordinator serves twoÂ roles.

First, itâ€™s an HTTP proxy. It receives search/indexing requests and forwards them to ES. Since it communicates via internal DNS within the same Kubernetes cluster, additional latency is negligible.

Second, itâ€™s a warm-up orchestrator. It determines which nodes can participate in search and manages that state. Nodes receiving termination signals are immediately removed from search targets, and newly started nodes are only added to search targets after warm-up is complete.

4.2. Controlling Search Target Nodes with prefer_nodes

The list of data nodes eligible for search is managed through CentralÂ Dogma.

prefer_nodes is the list of data nodes currently eligible for search. Newly started nodes are not included until they pass warm-up. The warmup section defines criteria for warm-up evaluation - QPS, latency thresholds, minimum/maximum duration - which can be configured differently perÂ cluster.

When search-coordinator receives a search request, it only sends it to Elasticsearch data nodes registered in Central Dogma. This enabled us to build a structure where search traffic doesnâ€™t flow to nodes that are still warmingÂ up.

4.3. search-coordinator as the Single StateÂ Manager

Thereâ€™s a clear reason we limited Central Dogma reads and writes to search-coordinator alone.

First, we wanted to maintain a Single Source of Truth for node routing state. We wanted to keep â€œwhich nodes are search-serving targetsâ€ in one place. If multiple servers each queried Elasticsearch to determine â€œwhich nodes are currently usable,â€ states would diverge based on polling timing, and debugging points would multiply exponentially.

Second, we wanted to fully encapsulate routing policy in one component. If decisions like including/excluding data nodes from search targets, warm-up success/failure, and exception handling all happen within search-coordinator, other modules donâ€™t need to know ESâ€™s internal state. Conversely, if applications or batch scripts directly modify the node list, tracking â€œwho changed what, when, and whyâ€ becomes difficult.

5. search-coordinator Warm-Up Orchestration Architecture

Letâ€™s look in more detail at the process from when a node goes down to when it rejoins. Elasticsearch data nodes run as Pods in a Kubernetes StatefulSet. search-coordinator operates in sync with the lifecycle of these data nodeÂ Pods.

5.1. When a Node Goes Down: prestop & excludeÂ Phases

Phases (1) prestop and (2) exclude in the diagram above are the process of safely removing a data node fromÂ serving.

When a data node goes down, search-coordinator performs two main tasks. Just before the ES data node Pod terminates, a preStop script runs and sends information about the soon-to-terminate node to search-coordinator. Then search-coordinator first removes (excludes) that node from prefer_nodes in Central Dogma to stop search traffic from flowing to it. Next, it adds the same node to a warm-up queue based on a Redis Sorted Set. We use timestamps as scores so we can later dequeue the oldest nodesÂ first.

Fallback for preStop HookÂ Failures

preStop hooks can fail or not be called at all. To handle this, we have a search-coordinator-controller module that subscribes to Elasticsearch data node Pod events via a Kubernetes Informer. If preStop wasnâ€™t called but the Pod enters Terminating state, the Informer detects this and the controller performs the same tasks. This provides a safety net that doesnâ€™t rely solely on preStop hooks but also validates against the Podâ€™s actual lifecycle.

5.2. Real Traffic-Based Warm-Up: warmupÂ Phase

Phase (3) warmup in the diagram is the process of populating the cache for a cache-cold node.

When a node comes back up, warm-up begins in earnest. However, if multiple search-coordinator Pods warm up the same node simultaneously, it can cause problems, so we first need to determine â€œwho will warm up thisÂ node.â€

Using Redis Distributed Locks to Assign Warm-Up Responsibility

We designed warm-up so that exactly one search-coordinator Pod handles it. If multiple Pods simultaneously attempt warm-up on the same data node, duplicate queries hit the same shards, creating unnecessary load and in some cases, ES might return 429 Too Many Requests errors. Conversely, a single Pod can generate sufficient QPS forÂ warm-up.

So we use a Redis distributed lock to decide â€œwho is responsible for this nodeâ€™s warm-up.â€ All warm-up workers poll the Redis warm-up queue, and when they detect the same node, only the Pod that acquires the lock first proceeds with warm-up. Other Pods skip immediately if theyâ€™re not the lock owner, guaranteeing single search-coordinator warm-up per node. Lock tokens are formatted as podIP/podName-timestamp-randomHex for easy tracking of which Pod holds theÂ lock.

Collecting Warm-UpÂ Queries

We decided to use production traffic patterns directly for warm-up queries. We stream all search request logs to a Kafka topic, and the search-coordinator worker responsible for warm-up consumes this topic in real-time to build a query pool. When warm-up starts, it pulls requests from this pool and sends them concentrated to the warm-up targetÂ node.

Queries dequeued arenâ€™t used just once and discardedâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re reused up to 5 times. When Elasticsearch builds query caches, it applies a minimum frequency condition, so a single request isnâ€™t enough to create a cacheÂ entry.

Looking at Luceneâ€™s minFrequencyToCache() method used by Elasticsearch, the same query needs to come in at least 2 times (or 5 times depending on conditions) to become a caching candidate. If we sent every query just once, we'd increase disk I/O without actually building caches. So we force cache creation with a "real traffic + repeated identical queries" combination.

5.3. Warm-Up Completion and Traffic Serving: warmup pass & include & serve trafficÂ Phases

Phases (4) warmup pass, (5) include, and (6) serve traffic in the diagram are the process of evaluating whether warm-up is complete for a node, and if passed, adding it to prefer_nodes to receive actual searchÂ traffic.

Query send rate follows the QPS (Queries Per Second) setting defined in Central Dogma. Response latency is tracked by storing the most recent N requests in a Circular Buffer and calculating p50 and p90 latency at configured intervals to check if they meet the criteria.

Warm-up success requires three conditions: total request count meets the minimum threshold, minimum execution time has elapsed, and recent response p50 and p90 latency are both within thresholds. When all conditions are met, warm-up is judged successful, the node is removed from the Redis warm-up queue, and added to prefer_nodes in Central Dogma to receive searchÂ traffic.

Warm-Up Failure andÂ Retry

If maximum execution time is reached without meeting criteria, warm-up is judged as failed. In this case, the node is not removed from the warm-up queue. The worker releases the lock and exits. Another search-coordinator Pod then acquires the lock and retries warm-up. Even with temporary network delays or Kafka lag, the system can recover through self-retry.

5.4. Safeguards to Prevent ShardÂ Shortage

To warm up a data node, we first need to exclude it from search targets. The problem is that if this is applied to multiple nodes simultaneously, situations can arise where â€œboth primary and replica for this shard are warming up, making search completely impossible.â€ So we added safeguards with the goal of â€œwarm up, but never create a situation where shards become unavailable.â€

To enforce this limit, we periodically check the warm-up queue. If 3 or more nodes are queued, we stop warm-up for the oldest node (by timestamp) and immediately return it to the prefer_nodes search target set. In this case, warm-up isn't 100% complete, but since caches warm up quickly once real traffic starts, latency stabilizes soon.
